books.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 1

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 1:1
verses.text: Fragments from the Lost Writings of Irenaeus  Chapter 1  I adjure thee, who shalt transcribe this book, by our Lord Jesus Christ, and by His glorious appearing, when He comes to judge the living and the dead, that thou compare what thou hast transcribed, and be careful to set it right according to this copy from which thou hast transcribed; also, that thou in like manner copy down this adjuration, and insert it in the transcript.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 2

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 2:1
verses.text: Chapter 2  These opinions, Florinus, that I may speak in mild terms, are not of sound doctrine; these opinions are not consonant to the Church, and involve their votaries in the utmost impiety; these opinions, even the heretics beyond the Church's pale have never ventured to broach; these opinions, those presbyters who preceded us, and who were conversant with the apostles, did not hand down to thee.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 2:2
verses.text: For, while I was yet a boy, I saw thee in Lower Asia with Polycarp, distinguishing thyself in the royal court, and endeavouring to gain his approbation.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 2:3
verses.text: For I have a more vivid recollection of what occurred at that time than of recent events (inasmuch as the experiences of childhood, keeping pace with the growth of the soul, become incorporated with it); so that I can even describe the place where the blessed Polycarp used to sit and discourse— his going out, too, and his coming in—his general mode of life and personal appearance, together with the discourses which he delivered to the people; also how he would speak of his familiar intercourse with John, and with the rest of those who had seen the Lord; and how he would call their words to remembrance.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 2:4
verses.text: Whatsoever things he had heard from them respecting the Lord, both with regard to His miracles and His teaching, Polycarp having thus received information from the eye-witnesses of the Word of life, would recount them all in harmony with the Scriptures.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 2:5
verses.text: These things, through, God's mercy which was upon me, I then listened to attentively, and treasured them up not on paper, but in my heart; and I am continually, by God's grace, revolving these things accurately in my mind.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 2:6
verses.text: And I can bear witness before God, that if that blessed and apostolical presbyter had heard any such thing, he would have cried out, and stopped his ears, exclaiming as he was wont to do: "O good God, for what times hast Thou reserved me, that I should endure these things?" And he would have fled from the very spot where, sitting or standing, he had heard such words.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 2:7
verses.text: This fact, too, can be made clear, from his Epistles which he despatched, whether to the neighbouring Churches to confirm them, or to certain of the brethren, admonishing and exhorting them.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 3

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 3:1
verses.text: Chapter 3  For the controversy is not merely as regards the day, but also as regards the form itself of the fast.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 3:2
verses.text: For some consider themselves bound to fast one day, others two days, others still more, while others do so during forty: the diurnal and the nocturnal hours they measure out together as their fasting day.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 3:3
verses.text: And this variety among the observers of the fasts had not its origin in our time, but long before in that of our predecessors, some of whom probably, being not very accurate in their observance of it,  handed down to posterity the custom as it had, through simplicity or private fancy, been introduced among them.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 3:4
verses.text: And yet nevertheless all these lived in peace one with another, and we also keep peace together.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 3:5
verses.text: Thus, in fact, the difference in observing the fast establishes the harmony of our common faith.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 3:6
verses.text: And the presbyters preceding Soter in the government of the Church which thou dost now rule—I mean, Anicetus and Pius, Hyginus and Telesphorus, and Sixtus—did neither themselves observe it after that fashion, nor permit those with them to do so.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 3:7
verses.text: Notwithstanding this, those who did not keep the feast in this way were peacefully disposed towards those who came to them from other dioceses in which it was so observed although such observance was felt in more decided contrariety as presented to those who did not fall in with it; and none were ever cast out of the Church for this matter.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 3:8
verses.text: On the contrary, those presbyters who preceded thee, and who did not observe this custom, sent the Eucharist to those of other dioceses who did observe it.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 3:9
verses.text: And when the blessed Polycarp was sojourning in Rome in the time of Anicetus, although a slight controversy had arisen among them as to certain other points, they were at once well inclined towards each other with regard to the matter in hand, not willing that any quarrel should arise between them upon this head.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 3:10
verses.text: For neither could Anicetus persuade Polycarp to forego the observance in his own way, inasmuch as these things had been always so observed by John the disciple of our Lord, and by other apostles with whom he had been conversant; nor, on the other hand, could Polycarp succeed in persuading Anicetus to keep the observance in his way, for he maintained that he was bound to adhere to the usage of the presbyters who preceded him.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 3:11
verses.text: And in this state of affairs they held fellowship with each other; and Anicetus conceded to Polycarp in the Church the celebration of the Eucharist, by way of showing him respect; so that they parted in peace one from the other, maintaining peace with the whole Church, both those who did observe this custom and those who did not.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 4

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 4:1
verses.text: Chapter 4  As long as any one has the means of doing good to his neighbours, and does not do so, he shall be reckoned a stranger to the love of the Lord.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 5

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 5:1
verses.text: Chapter 5  The will and the energy of God is the effective and foreseeing cause of every time and place and age, and of every nature.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 5:2
verses.text: The will is the reason (λόγος) of the intellectual soul, which reason is within us, inasmuch as it is the faculty belonging to it which is endowed with freedom of action.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 5:3
verses.text: The will is the mind desiring some object, and an appetite possessed of intelligence, yearning after that thing which is desired.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 6

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 6:1
verses.text: Chapter 6  Since God is vast, and the Architect of the world, and omnipotent, He created things that reach to immensity both by the Architect of the world and by an omnipotent will, and with a new effect, potently and efficaciously, in order that the entire fulness of those things which have been produced might come into being, although they had no previous existence—that is, whatever does not fall under our observation, and also what lies before our eyes.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 6:2
verses.text: And so does He contain all things in particular, and leads them on to their own proper result, on account of which they were called into being and produced, in no way changed into anything else than what it (the end) had originally been by nature.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 6:3
verses.text: For this is the property of the working of God, not merely to proceed to the infinitude of the understanding, or even to overpass our powers of mind, reason and speech, time and place, and every age; but also to go beyond substance, and fulness or perfection.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 7

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 7:1
verses.text: Chapter 7  This custom, of not bending the knee upon Sunday, is a symbol of the resurrection, through which we have been set free, by the grace of Christ, from sins, and from death, which has been put to death under Him.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 7:2
verses.text: Now this custom took its rise from apostolic times, as the blessed Irenaeus, the martyr and bishop of Lyons, declares in his treatise On Easter, in which he makes mention of Pentecost also; upon which feast we do not bend the knee, because it is of equal significance with the Lord's day, for the reason already alleged concerning it.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 8

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 8:1
verses.text: Chapter 8  For as the ark of the covenant was gilded within and without with pure gold, so was also the body of Christ pure and resplendent; for it was adorned within by the Word, and shielded without by the Spirit, in order that from both materials the splendour of the natures might be clearly shown forth.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 9

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 9:1
verses.text: Chapter 9  Ever, indeed, speaking well of the deserving, but never ill of the undeserving, we also shall attain to the glory and kingdom of God.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 10

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 10:1
verses.text: Chapter 10  It is indeed proper to God, and befitting His character, to show mercy and pity, and to bring salvation to His creatures, even though they be brought under danger of destruction.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 10:2
verses.text: "For with Him," says the Scripture, "is propitiation".

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 11

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 11:1
verses.text: Chapter 11   The business of the Christian is nothing else than to be ever preparing for death (μελεπᾷν ἀποθνήσκειν).

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 12

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 12:1
verses.text: Chapter 12  We therefore have formed the belief that our bodies also do rise again.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 12:2
verses.text: For although they go to corruption, yet they do not perish; for the earth, receiving the remains, preserves them, even like fertile seed mixed with more fertile ground.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 12:3
verses.text: Again, as a bare grain is sown, and, germinating by the command of God its Creator, rises again, clothed upon and glorious, but not before it has died and suffered decomposition, and become mingled with the earth; so it is seen from this, that we have not entertained a vain belief in the resurrection of the body.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 12:4
verses.text: But although it is dissolved at the appointed time, because of the primeval disobedience, it is placed, as it were, in the crucible of the earth, to be recast again; not then as this corruptible body, but pure, and no longer subject to decay: so that to each body its own soul shall be restored; and when it is clothed upon with this, it shall not experience sorrow, but shall rejoice, continuing permanently in a state of purity, having for its companion a just consort, not an insidious one, possessing in every respect the things pertaining to it, it shall receive these with perfect accuracy; it shall not receive bodies diverse from what they had been, nor delivered from suffering or disease, nor as rendered glorious, but as they departed this life, in sins or in righteous actions: and such as they were, such shall they be clothed with upon resuming life; and such as they were in unbelief, such shall they be faithfully judged.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 13

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 13:1
verses.text: Chapter 13  For when the Greeks, having arrested the slaves of Christian catechumens, then used force against them, in order to learn from them some secret thing practised among Christians, these slaves, having nothing to say that would meet the wishes of their tormentors, except that they had heard from their masters that the divine communion was the body and blood of Christ, and imagining that it was actually flesh and blood, gave their inquisitors answer to that effect.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 13:2
verses.text: Then these latter, assuming such to be the case with regard to the practices of Christians, gave information regarding it to other Greeks, and sought to compel the martyrs Sanctus and Blandina to confess, under the influence of torture, that the allegation was correct.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 13:3
verses.text: To these men Blandina replied very admirably in these words: "How should those persons endure such accusations, who, for the sake of the practice of piety, did not avail themselves even of the flesh that was permitted them to eat?".

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 14

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 14:1
verses.text: Chapter 14  How is it possible to say that the serpent, created by God dumb and irrational, was endowed with reason and speech? For if it had the power of itself to speak, to discern, to understand, and to reply to what was spoken by the woman, there would have been nothing to prevent every serpent from doing this also.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 14:2
verses.text: If, however, they say again that it was according to the divine will and dispensation that this serpent spake with a human voice to Eve, they render God the author of sin.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 14:3
verses.text: Neither was it possible for the evil demon to impart speech to a speechless nature, and thus from that which is not to produce that which is; for if that were the case, he never would have ceased (with the view of leading men astray) from conferring with and deceiving them by means of serpents, and beasts, and birds.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 14:4
verses.text: From what quarter, too, did it, being a beast, obtain information regarding the injunction  of God to the man given to him alone, and in secret, not even the woman herself being aware of it? Why also did it not prefer to make its attack upon the man instead of the woman? And if thou sayest that it attacked her as being the weaker of the two, I reply that, on the contrary, she was the stronger, since she appears to have been the helper of the man in the transgression of the commandment.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 14:5
verses.text: For she did by herself alone resist the serpent, and it was after holding out for a while and making opposition that she ate of the tree, being circumvented by craft; whereas Adam, making no fight whatever, nor refusal, partook of the fruit handed to him by the woman, which is an indication of the utmost imbecility and effeminacy of mind.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 14:6
verses.text: And the woman indeed, having been vanquished in the contest by a demon, is deserving of pardon; but Adam shall deserve none, for he was worsted by a woman,—he who, in his own person, had received the command from God.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 14:7
verses.text: But the woman, having heard of the command from Adam, treated it with contempt, either because she deemed it unworthy of God to speak by means of it, or because she had her doubts, perhaps even held the opinion that the command was given to her by Adam of his own accord.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 14:8
verses.text: The serpent found her working alone, so that he was enabled to confer with her apart.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 14:9
verses.text: Observing her then either eating or not eating from the trees, he put before her the fruit of the forbidden tree.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 14:10
verses.text: And if he saw her eating, it is manifest that she was partaker of a body subject to corruption.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 14:11
verses.text: "For everything going in at the mouth, is cast out into the draught".

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 14:12
verses.text: If then corruptible, it is obvious that she was also mortal.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 14:13
verses.text: But if mortal, then there was certainly no curse; nor was that a condemnatory sentence, when the voice of God spake to the man, "For earth thou art, and unto earth shall thou return," as the true course of things proceeds now and always.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 14:14
verses.text: Then again, if the serpent observed the woman not eating, how did he induce her to eat who never had eaten? And who pointed out to this accursed man-slaying serpent that the sentence of death pronounced against them by God would not take immediate effect, when He said, "For in the day that ye eat thereof, ye shall surely die?" And not this merely, but that along with the impunity attending their sin the eyes of those should be opened who had not seen until then? But with the opening of their eyes referred to, they made entrance upon the path of death.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 15

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 15:1
verses.text: Chapter 15  When, in times of old, Balaam spake these things in parables, he was not acknowledged; and now, when Christ has appeared and fulfilled them, He was not believed.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 15:2
verses.text: Wherefore Balaam, foreseeing this, and wondering at it, exclaimed, "Alas! alas! who shall live when God brings these things to pass?".

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 16

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 16:1
verses.text: Chapter 16  Expounding again the law to that generation which followed those who were slain in the wilderness, he published Deuteronomy; not as giving to them a different law from that which had been appointed for their fathers, but as recapitulating this latter, in order that they, by hearing what had happened to their fathers, might fear God with their whole heart.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 17

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 17:1
verses.text: Chapter 17  By these Christ was typified, and acknowledged, and brought into the world; for He was prefigured in Joseph: then from Levi and Judah He was descended according to the flesh, as King and Priest; and He was acknowledged by Simeon in the temple: through Zebulon He was believed in among the Gentiles, as says the prophet, "the land of Zabulon;" and through Benjamin that is, Paul He was glorified, by being preached throughout all the world.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 18

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 18:1
verses.text: Chapter 18  And this was not without meaning; but that by means of the number of the ten men, he (Gideon) might appear as having Jesus for a helper, as is indicated by the compact entered into with them.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 18:2
verses.text: And when he did not choose to partake with them in their idol-worship, they threw the blame upon him: for "Jerubbaal" signifies the judgment-seat of Baal.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 19

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 19:1
verses.text: Chapter 19  "Take unto thee Joshua (᾽Ιησοῦν) the son of Nun".

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 19:2
verses.text: For it was proper that Moses should lead the people out of Egypt, but that Jesus (Joshua) should lead them into the inheritance.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 19:3
verses.text: Also that Moses, as was the case with the law, should cease to be, but that Joshua (᾽Ιησοῦν), as the word, and no untrue type of the Word made  flesh (ἐνυποστάτου), should be a preacher to the people.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 19:4
verses.text: Then again, it was fit that Moses should give manna as food to the fathers, but Joshua wheat; as the first-fruits of life, a type of the body of Christ, as also the Scripture declares that the manna of the Lord ceased when the people had eaten wheat from the land.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 20

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 20:1
verses.text: Chapter 20  "And he laid his hands upon him".

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 20:2
verses.text: The countenance of Joshua was also glorified by the imposition of the hands of Moses, but not to the same degree as that of Moses.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 20:3
verses.text: Inasmuch, then, as he had obtained a certain degree of grace, the Lord said, "And thou shall confer upon him of thy glory".

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 20:4
verses.text: For in this case the thing given does not cease to belong to the giver.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 21

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 21:1
verses.text: Chapter 21  But he does not give, as Christ did, by means of breathing, because he is not the fount of the Spirit.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 22

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 22:1
verses.text: Chapter 22  "Thou shall not go with them, neither shalt thou curse the people".

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 22:2
verses.text: He does not hint at anything with regard to the people, for they all lay before his view, but he refers to the mystery of Christ pointed out beforehand.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 22:3
verses.text: For as He was to be born of the fathers according to the flesh, the Spirit gives instructions to the man (Balaam) beforehand, lest, going forth in ignorance, he might pronounce a curse upon the people.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 22:4
verses.text: Not, indeed, that his curse could take any effect contrary to the will of God; but this was done as an exhibition of the providence of God which He exercised towards them on account of their forefathers.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 23

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 23:1
verses.text: Chapter 23  "And he mounted upon his ass".

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 23:2
verses.text: The ass was the type of the body of Christ, upon whom all men, resting from their labours, are borne as in a chariot.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 23:3
verses.text: For the Saviour has taken up the burden of our sins.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 23:4
verses.text: Now the angel who appeared to Balaam was the Word Himself; and in His hand He held a sword, to indicate the power which He had from above.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 24

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 24:1
verses.text: Chapter 24  "God is not as a man".

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 24:2
verses.text: He thus shows that all men are indeed guilty of falsehood, inasmuch as they change from one thing to another (μεταφερόμενοι); but such is not the case with God, for He always continues true, perfecting whatever He wishes.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 25

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 25:1
verses.text: Chapter 25  "To inflict vengeance from the Lord on Midian".

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 25:2
verses.text: For this man (Balaam), when he speaks no longer in the Spirit of God, but contrary to God's law, by setting up a different law with regard to fornication, is certainly not then to be counted as a prophet, but as a soothsayer.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 25:3
verses.text: For he who did not keep to the commandment of God, received the just recompense of his own evil devices.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 26

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 26:1
verses.text: Chapter 26  Know thou that every man is either empty or full.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 26:2
verses.text: For if he has not the Holy Spirit, he has no knowledge of the Creator; he has not received Jesus Christ the Life; he knows not the Father who is in heaven; if he does not live after the dictates of reason, after the heavenly law, he is not a sober-minded person, nor does he act uprightly: such an one is empty.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 26:3
verses.text: If, on the other hand, he receives God, who says, "I will dwell with them, and walk in them, and I will be their God," such an one is not empty, but full.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 27

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 27:1
verses.text: Chapter 27  The little boy, therefore, who guided Samson by the hand, pre-typified John the Baptist, who showed to the people the faith in Christ.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 27:2
verses.text: And the house in which they were assembled signifies the world, in which dwell the various heathen and unbelieving nations, offering sacrifice to their idols.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 27:3
verses.text: Moreover, the two pillars are the two covenants.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 27:4
verses.text: The fact, then, of Samson leaning himself upon the pillars, indicates this, that the people, when instructed, recognized the mystery of Christ.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 28

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 28:1
verses.text: Chapter 28  "And the man of God said, Where did it fall? And he showed him the place.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 28:2
verses.text: And he cut down a tree, and cast it in there, and the iron floated".

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 28:3
verses.text: This was a sign that souls should be borne aloft (ἀναγωγῆς ψυχῶν) through the instrumentality of wood, upon which He suffered who can lead those souls aloft that follow His ascension.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 28:4
verses.text: This event was also an indication of the fact, that when the holy soul of Christ descended to Hades, many souls ascended and were seen in their bodies.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 28:5
verses.text: For just as the wood, which is the lighter body, was submerged in the water; but the iron, the heavier one, floated: so, when the Word of God became one with flesh, by a physical and hypostatic union, the heavy and terrestrial part, having been rendered immortal, was borne up into heaven, by the divine nature, after the resurrection.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 29

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 29:1
verses.text: Chapter 29  The Gospel according to Matthew was written to the Jews.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 29:2
verses.text: For they laid particular stress upon the fact that Christ should be of the seed of David.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 29:3
verses.text: Matthew also, who had a still greater desire to establish this point, took particular pains to afford them convincing proof that Christ is of the seed of David; and therefore he commences with an account of His genealogy.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 30

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 30:1
verses.text: Chapter 30  "The axe unto the root," he says, urging us to the knowledge of the truth, and purifying us by means of fear, as well as preparing us to bring forth fruit in due season.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 31

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 31:1
verses.text: Chapter 31  Observe that, by means of the grain of mustard seed in the parable, the heavenly doctrine is denoted which is sown like seed in the world, as in a field, seed which has an inherent force, fiery and powerful.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 31:2
verses.text: For the Judge of the whole world is thus proclaimed, who, having been hidden in the heart of the earth in a tomb for three days, and having become a great tree, has stretched forth His branches to the ends of the earth.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 31:3
verses.text: Sprouting out from Him, the twelve apostles, having become fair and fruitful boughs, were made a shelter for the nations as for the fowls of heaven, under which boughs, all having taken refuge, as birds flocking to a nest, have been made partakers of that wholesome and celestial food which is derived from them.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 32

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 32:1
verses.text: Chapter 32  Josephus says, that when Moses had been brought up in the royal palaces, he was chosen as general against the Ethiopians; and having proved victorious, obtained in marriage the daughter of that king, since indeed, out of her affection for him, she delivered the city up to him.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 32:2
verses.text: Why was it, that when these two (Aaron and Miriam) had both acted with despite towards him (Moses), the latter alone was adjudged punishment? First, because the woman was the more culpable, since both nature and the law place the woman in a subordinate condition to the man.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 32:3
verses.text: Or perhaps it was that Aaron was to a certain degree excusable, in consideration of his being the elder brother, and adorned with the dignity of high priest.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 32:4
verses.text: Then again, inasmuch as the leper was accounted by the law unclean, while at the same time the origin and foundation of the priesthood lay in Aaron, the Lord did not award a similar punishment to him, lest this stigma should attach itself to the entire sacerdotal race; but by means of his sister's example He awoke his fears, and taught him the same lesson.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 32:5
verses.text: For Miriam's punishment affected him to such an extent, that no sooner did she experience it, than he entreated Moses, who had been injured, that he would by his intercession do away with the affliction.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 32:6
verses.text: And he did not neglect to do so, but at once poured forth his supplication.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 32:7
verses.text: Upon this the Lord, who loves mankind, made him understand how He had not chastened her as a judge, but as a father; for He said, "If her father had spit in her face, should she not be ashamed? Let her be shut out from the camp seven days, and after that let her come in again".

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 33

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 33:1
verses.text: Chapter 33  Inasmuch as certain men, impelled by what considerations I know not, remove from God the half of His creative power, by asserting that He is merely the cause of quality resident in matter, and by maintaining that matter itself is uncreated, come now let us put the question, What is at any time … is immutable.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 33:2
verses.text: Matter, then, is immutable.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 33:3
verses.text: But if matter be immutable, and the immutable suffers no change in regard to quality, it does not form the substance of the world.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 33:4
verses.text: For which reason it seems to them superfluous, that God has annexed qualities to matter, since indeed matter admits of no possible alteration, it being in itself an uncreated thing.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 33:5
verses.text: But further, if matter be uncreated, it has been made altogether according to a certain quality, and this immutable, so that it cannot be receptive of more qualities, nor can it be the thing of which the world is made.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 33:6
verses.text: But if the world be not made from it, this theory entirely excludes God from exercising power on the creation of the world.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 34

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 34:1
verses.text: Chapter 34  "And dipped himself," says the Scripture, "seven times in Jordan".

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 34:2
verses.text: It was not for nothing that Naaman of old, when suffering from leprosy, was purified upon his being baptized, but it served as an indication to us.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 34:3
verses.text: For as we are lepers in sin, we are made clean, by means of the sacred water and the invocation of the Lord, from our old transgressions; being spiritually regenerated as new-born babes, even as the Lord has declared: "Except a man be born again through water and the Spirit, he shall not enter into the kingdom of heaven".

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 35

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 35:1
verses.text: Chapter 35  If the corpse of Elisha raised a dead man, how much more shall God, when He has quickened men's dead bodies, bring them up for judgment?.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 36

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 36:1
verses.text: Chapter 36  True knowledge, then, consists in the understanding of Christ, which Paul terms the wisdom of God hidden in a mystery, which "the natural man receiveth not," the doctrine of the cross; of which if any man "taste," he will not accede to the disputations and quibbles of proud and puffed-up men, who go into matters of which they have no perception.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 36:2
verses.text: For the truth is unsophisticated (ἀσχημάτιστος); and "the word is nigh thee, in thy mouth and in thy heart," as the same apostle declares, being easy of comprehension to those who are obedient.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 36:3
verses.text: For it renders us like to Christ, if we experience "the power of his resurrection and the fellowship of His sufferings".

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 36:4
verses.text: For this is the affinity of the apostolical teaching and the most holy "faith delivered unto us," which the unlearned receive, and those of slender knowledge have taught, not "giving heed to endless genealogies," but studying rather to observe a straightforward course of life; lest, having been deprived of the Divine Spirit, they fail to attain to the kingdom of heaven.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 36:5
verses.text: For truly the first thing is to deny one's self and to follow Christ; and those who do this are borne onward to perfection, having fulfilled all their Teacher's will, becoming sons of God by spiritual regeneration, and heirs of the kingdom of heaven; those who seek which first shall not be forsaken.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 37

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 37:1
verses.text: Chapter 37  Those who have become acquainted with the secondary ( i-e:, under Christ) constitutions of the apostles, are aware that the Lord instituted a new oblation in the new covenant, according to the declaration of Malachi the prophet.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 37:2
verses.text: For, "from the rising of the sun even to the setting my name has been glorified among the Gentiles, and in every place incense is offered to my name, and a pure sacrifice;" as John also declares in the Apocalypse: "The incense is the prayers of the saints".

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 37:3
verses.text: Then again, Paul exhorts us "to present our bodies a living sacrifice, holy, acceptable unto God, which is your reasonable service".

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 37:4
verses.text: And again, "Let us offer the sacrifice of praise, that is, the fruit of the lips".

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 37:5
verses.text: Now those oblations are not according to the law, the handwriting of which the Lord took away from the midst by cancelling it; but they are according to the Spirit, for we must worship God "in spirit and in truth".

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 37:6
verses.text: And therefore the oblation of the Eucharist is not a carnal one, but a spiritual; and in this respect it is pure.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 37:7
verses.text: For we make an oblation to God of the bread and the cup of blessing, giving Him thanks in that He has commanded the earth to bring forth these fruits for our nourishment.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 37:8
verses.text: And then, when we have perfected the oblation, we invoke the Holy Spirit, that He may exhibit this sacrifice, both the bread the body of Christ, and the cup the blood of Christ, in order that the receivers of these antitypes may obtain remission of sins and life eternal.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 37:9
verses.text: Those persons, then, who perform these oblations in remembrance of the Lord, do not fall in with Jewish views, but, performing the service after a spiritual manner, they shall be called sons of wisdom.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 38

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 38:1
verses.text: Chapter 38  The apostles ordained, that "we should not judge any one in respect to meat or drink, or in regard to a feast day, or the new moons, or the sabbaths".

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 38:2
verses.text: Whence then these contentions? whence these schisms? We keep the feast, but in the leaven of malice and wickedness, cutting in pieces the Church of God; and we preserve what belongs to its exterior, that we may cast away these better things, faith and love.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 38:3
verses.text: We have heard from the prophetic words that these feasts and fasts are displeasing to the Lord.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 39

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 39:1
verses.text: Chapter 39  Christ, who was called the Son of God before the ages, was manifested in the fulness of time, in order that He might cleanse us through His blood, who were under the power of sin, presenting us as pure sons to His Father, if we yield ourselves obediently to the chastisement of the Spirit.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 39:2
verses.text: And in the end of time He shall come to do away with all evil, and to reconcile all things, in order that there may be an end of all impurities.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 40

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 40:1
verses.text: Chapter 40  "And he found the jaw-bone of an ass".

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 40:2
verses.text: It is to be observed that, after Samson had committed fornication, the holy Scripture no longer speaks of the things happily accomplished by him in connection with the formula, "The Spirit of the Lord came upon him".

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 40:3
verses.text: For thus, according to the holy apostle, the sin of fornication is perpetrated against the body, as involving also sin against the temple of God.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 41

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 41:1
verses.text: Chapter 41  This indicates the persecution against the Church set on foot by the nations who still continue in unbelief.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 41:2
verses.text: But he (Samson) who suffered those things, trusted that there would be a retaliation against those waging this war.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 41:3
verses.text: But retaliation through what means? First of all, by his betaking himself to the Rock not cognizable to the senses; secondly, by the finding of the jaw-bone of an ass.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 41:4
verses.text: Now the type of the jaw-bone is the body of Christ.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 42

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 42:1
verses.text: Chapter 42  Speaking always well of the worthy, but never ill of the unworthy, we also shall attain to the glory and kingdom of God.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 43

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 43:1
verses.text: Chapter 43  In these things there was signified by prophecy that the people, having become transgressors, shall be bound by the chains of their own sins.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 43:2
verses.text: But the breaking of the bonds of their own accord indicates that, upon repentance, they shall be again loosed from the shackles of sin.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 44

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 44:1
verses.text: Chapter 44  It is not an easy thing for a soul, under the influence of error, to be persuaded of the contrary opinion.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 45

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 45:1
verses.text: Chapter 45  "And Balaam the son of Beor they slew with the sword".

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 45:2
verses.text: For, speaking no longer by the Spirit of God, but setting up another law of fornication contrary to the law of God, this man shall no longer be reckoned as a prophet, but as a soothsayer.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 45:3
verses.text: For, as he did not continue in the commandment of God, he received the just reward of his evil devices.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 46

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 46:1
verses.text: Chapter 46  "The god of the world;" that is, Satan, who was designated God to those who believe not.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 47

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 47:1
verses.text: Chapter 47  The birth of John the Baptist brought the dumbness of Zacharias to an end.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 47:2
verses.text: For he did not burden his father, when the voice issued forth from silence; but as when not believed it rendered him tongue-tied, so did the voice sounding out clearly set his father free, to whom he had both been announced and born.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 47:3
verses.text: Now the voice and the burning light were a precursor of the Word and the Light.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 48

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 48:1
verses.text: Chapter 48  As therefore seventy tongues are indicated by number, and from dispersion the tongues are gathered into one by means of their interpretation; so is that ark declared a type of the body of Christ, which is both pure and immaculate.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 48:2
verses.text: For as that ark was gilded with pure gold both within and without, so also is the body of Christ pure and resplendent, being adorned within by the Word, and shielded on the outside by the Spirit, in order that from both materials the splendour of the natures might be exhibited together.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 49

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 49:1
verses.text: Chapter 49  Now therefore, by means of this which has been already brought forth a long time since, the Word has assigned an interpretation.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 49:2
verses.text: We are convinced that there exist so to speak two men in each one of us.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 49:3
verses.text: The one is confessedly a hidden thing, while the other stands apparent; one is corporeal, the other spiritual; although the generation of both may be compared to that of twins.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 49:4
verses.text: For both are revealed to the world as but one, for the soul was not anterior to the body in its essence; nor, in regard to its formation, did the body precede the soul: but both these were produced at one time; and their nourishment consists in purity and sweetness.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 50

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 50:1
verses.text: Chapter 50  For then there shall in truth be a common joy consummated to all those who believe unto life, and in each individual shall be confirmed the mystery of the Resurrection, and the hope of incorruption, and the commencement of the eternal kingdom, when God shall have destroyed death and the devil.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 50:2
verses.text: For that human nature and flesh which has risen again from the dead shall die no more; but after it had been changed to incorruption, and made like to spirit, when the heaven was opened, our Lord full of glory offered it (the flesh) to the Father.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 51

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 51:1
verses.text: Chapter 51  Now, however, inasmuch as the books of these men may possibly have escaped your observation, but have come under our notice, I call your attention to them, that for the sake of your reputation you may expel these writings from among you, as bringing disgrace upon you, since their author boasts himself as being one of your company.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 51:2
verses.text: For they constitute a stumbling-block to many, who simply and unreservedly receive, as coming from a presbyter, the blasphemy which they utter against God.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 51:3
verses.text: Just consider the writer of these things, how by means of them he does not injure assistants in divine service only, who happen to be prepared in mind for blasphemies against God, but also damages those among us, since by his books he imbues their minds with false doctrines concerning God.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 52

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 52:1
verses.text: Chapter 52  The sacred books acknowledge with regard to Christ, that as He is the Son of man, so is the same Being not a mere man; and as He is flesh, so is He also spirit, and the Word of God, and God.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 52:2
verses.text: And as He was born of Mary in the last times, so did He also proceed from God as the First-begotten of every creature; and as He hungered, so did He satisfy others; and as He thirsted, so did He of old cause the Jews to drink, for the "Rock was Christ" Himself: thus does Jesus now give to His believing people power to drink spiritual waters, which spring up to life eternal.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 52:3
verses.text: And as He was the son of David, so was He also the Lord of David.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 52:4
verses.text: And as He was from Abraham, so did He also exist before Abraham.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 52:5
verses.text: And as He was the servant of God, so is He the Son of God, and Lord of the universe.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 52:6
verses.text: And as He was spit upon ignominiously, so also did He breathe the Holy Spirit into His disciples.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 52:7
verses.text: And as He was saddened, so also did He give joy to His people.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 52:8
verses.text: And as He was capable of being handled and touched, so again did He, in a non-apprehensible form, pass through the midst of those who sought to injure Him, and entered without impediment through closed doors.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 52:9
verses.text: And as He slept, so did He also rule the sea, the winds, and the storms.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 52:10
verses.text: And as He suffered, so also is He alive, and life-giving, and healing all our infirmity.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 52:11
verses.text: And as He died, so is He also the Resurrection of the dead.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 52:12
verses.text: He suffered shame on earth, while He is higher than all glory and praise in heaven; who, "though He was crucified through weakness, yet He liveth by divine power;" who "descended into the lower parts of the earth," and who "ascended up above the heavens;" for whom a manger sufficed, yet who filled all things; who was dead, yet who liveth for ever and ever, Amen.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 53

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 53:1
verses.text: Chapter 53  With regard to Christ, the law and the prophets and the evangelists have proclaimed that He was born of a virgin, that He suffered upon a beam of wood, and that He appeared from the dead; that He also ascended to the heavens, and was glorified by the Father, and is the Eternal King; that He is the perfect Intelligence, the Word of God, who was begotten before the light; that He was the Founder of the universe, along with it (light), and the Maker of man; that He is All in all: Patriarch among the patriarchs; Law in the laws; Chief Priest among priests; Ruler among kings; the Prophet among prophets; the Angel among angels; the Man among men; Son in the Father; God in God; King to all eternity.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 53:2
verses.text: For it is He who sailed in the ark along with Noah, and who guided Abraham; who was bound along with Isaac, and was a Wanderer with Jacob; the Shepherd of those who are saved, and the Bridegroom of the Church; the Chief also of the cherubim, the Prince of the angelic powers; God of God; Son of the Father; Jesus Christ; King for ever and ever, Amen.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 54

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 54:1
verses.text: Chapter 54  The law and the prophets and evangelists have declared that Christ was born of a virgin, and suffered on the cross; was raised also from the dead, and taken up to heaven; that He was glorified, and reigns for ever.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 54:2
verses.text: He is Himself termed the Perfect Intellect, the Word of God.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 54:3
verses.text: He is the First-begotten, after a transcendent manner, the Creator of man; All in all; Patriarch among the patriarchs; Law in the law; the Priest among priests; among kings Prime Leader; the Prophet among the prophets; the Angel among angels; the Man among men; Son in the Father; God in God; King to all eternity.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 54:4
verses.text: He was sold with Joseph, and He guided Abraham; was bound along with Isaac, and wandered with Jacob; with Moses He was Leader, and, respecting the people, Legislator.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 54:5
verses.text: He preached in the prophets; was incarnate of a virgin; born in Bethlehem; received by John, and baptized in Jordan; was tempted in the desert, and proved to be the Lord.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 54:6
verses.text: He gathered the apostles together, and preached the kingdom of heaven; gave light to the blind, and raised the dead; was seen in the temple, but was not held by the people as worthy of credit; was arrested by the priests, conducted before Herod, and condemned in the presence of Pilate; He manifested Himself in the body, was suspended upon a beam of wood, and raised from the dead; shown to the apostles, and, having been carried up to heaven, sitteth on the right hand of the Father, and has been glorified by Him as the Resurrection of the dead.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 54:7
verses.text: Moreover, He is the Salvation of the lost, the Light to those dwelling in darkness, and Redemption to those who have been born; the Shepherd of the saved, and the Bridegroom of the Church; the Charioteer of the cherubim, the Leader of the angelic host; God of God; Jesus Christ our Saviour.

chapters.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 55

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 55:1
verses.text: Chapter 55  "Then drew near unto Him the mother of Zebedee's children, with her sons, worshipping, and seeking a certain thing from Him".

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 55:2
verses.text: These people are certainly not void of understanding, nor are the words set forth in that passage of no signification: being stated beforehand like a preface, they have some agreement with those points formerly expounded.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 55:3
verses.text: "Then drew near".

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 55:4
verses.text: Sometimes virtue excites our admiration, not merely on account of the display which is given of it, but also of the occasion when it was manifested.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 55:5
verses.text: I may refer, for example, to the premature fruit of the grape, or of the fig, or to any fruit whatsoever, from which, during its process of growth, no man expects maturity or full development; yet, although any one may perceive that it is still somewhat imperfect, he does not for that reason despise as useless the immature grape when plucked, but he gathers it with pleasure as appearing early in the season; nor does he consider whether the grape is possessed of perfect sweetness; nay, he at once experiences satisfaction from the thought that this one has appeared before the rest.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 55:6
verses.text: Just in the same way does God also, when He perceives the faithful possessing wisdom though still imperfect, and but a small degree of faith, overlook their defect in this respect, and therefore does not reject them; nay, but on the contrary, He kindly welcomes and accepts them as premature fruits, and honours the mind, whatsoever it may be, which is stamped with virtue, although not yet perfect.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 55:7
verses.text: He makes allowance for it, as being among the harbingers of the vintage, and esteems it highly, inasmuch as, being of a readier disposition than the rest, it has forestalled, as it were, the blessing to itself.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 55:8
verses.text: Abraham therefore, Isaac, and Jacob, our fathers, are to be esteemed before all, since they did indeed afford us such early examples of virtue.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 55:9
verses.text: How many martyrs can be compared to Daniel? How many martyrs, I ask, can rival the three youths in Babylon, although the memory of the former has not been brought before us so conspicuously as that of the latter? These were truly first-fruits, and indications of the succeeding fructification.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 55:10
verses.text: Hence God has directed their life to be recorded, as a model for those who should come after.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 55:11
verses.text: And that their virtue was thus accepted by God, as the first-fruits of the produce, hear what He has Himself declared: "As a grape," He says, "I have found Israel in the wilderness, and as first-ripe figs your fathers".

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 55:12
verses.text: Call not therefore the faith of Abraham merely blessed because he believed.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 55:13
verses.text: Do you wish to look upon Abraham with admiration? Then behold how that one man alone professed piety when in the world six hundred had been contaminated with error.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 55:14
verses.text: Dost thou wish Daniel to carry thee away to amazement? Behold that city Babylon, haughty in the flower and pride of impiousness, and its inhabitants completely given over to sin of every description.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 55:15
verses.text: But he, emerging from the depth, spat out the brine of sins, and rejoiced to plunge into the sweet waters of piety.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 55:16
verses.text: And now, in like manner, with regard to that mother of Zebedee's children, do not admire merely what she said, but also the time at which she uttered these words.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 55:17
verses.text: For when was it that she drew near to the Redeemer? Not after the resurrection, nor after the preaching of His name, nor after the establishment of His kingdom; but it was when the Lord said, "Behold, we go up to Jerusalem, and the Son of man shall be delivered to the chief priests and the scribes; and they shall kill Him, and on the third day He shall rise again".

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 55:18
verses.text: These things the Saviour told in reference to His sufferings and cross; to these persons He predicted His passion.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 55:19
verses.text: Nor did He conceal the fact that it should be of a most ignominious kind, at the hands of the chief priests.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 55:20
verses.text: This woman, however, had attached another meaning to the dispensation of His sufferings.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 55:21
verses.text: The Saviour was foretelling death; and she asked for the glory of immortality.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 55:22
verses.text: The Lord was asserting that He must stand arraigned before impious judges; but she, taking no note of that judgment, requested as of the judge: "Grant," she said, "that these my two sons may sit, one on the right hand, and the other on the left, in Thy glory".

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 55:23
verses.text: In the one case the passion is referred to, in the other the kingdom is understood.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 55:24
verses.text: The Saviour was speaking of the cross, while she had in view the glory which admits no suffering.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 55:25
verses.text: This woman, therefore, as I have already said, is worthy of our admiration, not merely for what she sought, but also for the occasion of her making the request.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 55:26
verses.text: She did indeed suffer, not merely as a pious person, but also as a woman.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 55:27
verses.text: For, having been instructed by His words, she considered and believed that it would come to pass, that the kingdom of Christ should flourish in glory, and walk in its vastness throughout the world, and be increased by the preaching of piety.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 55:28
verses.text: She understood, as was in fact the case, that He who appeared in a lowly guise had delivered and received every promise.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 55:29
verses.text: I will inquire upon another occasion, when I come to treat upon this humility, whether the Lord rejected her petition concerning His kingdom.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 55:30
verses.text: But she thought that the same confidence would not be possessed by her, when, at the appearance of the angels, He should be ministered to by the angels, and receive service from the entire heavenly host.

verses.name: Irenaeus: Fragments from the Lost Writings 55:31
verses.text: Taking the Saviour, therefore, apart in a retired place, she earnestly desired of Him those things which transcend every human nature.
